title: 107_hr4503
content: The "Caribbean Amnesty and Relief Act" clarifies eligibility for relief from removal and deportation for certain Caribbean aliens by allowing adjustment of status for certain Caribbeans. The "Caribbean Amnesty and Relief Act" allows for the adjustment of status for certain Caribbean aliens to obtain lawful permanent residence, bypassing certain grounds for inadmissibility. Alien present in the US under certain orders may apply for adjustment of status without needing to file a separate motion. If the application is granted, the order will be canceled; if denied, the order remains enforceable. Aliens from Caribbean countries present in the US since September 30, 1996, can apply for adjustment of status. Continuous physical presence is required, with absences not exceeding 180 days. Proof of presence before the specified date is necessary for the application. Aliens present in the US since September 30, 1996, can apply for adjustment of status by demonstrating prior service or physical presence. The Attorney General can provide regulations for this process, including seeking a stay of deportation or removal. Aliens in exclusion, deportation, or removal proceedings can apply for adjustment of status under certain conditions. The Attorney General can authorize employment for these aliens during the application process, and for spouses and children as well. Aliens in exclusion, deportation, or removal proceedings can apply for adjustment of status under certain conditions. The Attorney General can authorize employment for these aliens during the application process, and for spouses and children as well. The status of an alien from a Caribbean country can be adjusted to that of an alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence if they meet specific criteria. Aliens in exclusion, deportation, or removal proceedings can apply for adjustment of status under specific conditions, including being physically present in the US when the application is filed and meeting eligibility criteria for an immigrant visa. Proof of continuous presence is required for this purpose. In 2003, aliens seeking adjustment of status must prove continuous physical presence starting no later than December 1, 1995, and can be absent from the US for up to 180 days. The Attorney General must offer administrative review rights to applicants under subsection (a) similar to those under section 245. The Attorney General's determination on adjusting an alien's status under section 245 or in removal proceedings under section 240 is final and not subject to judicial review. When an alien is granted permanent residence status, the Secretary of State is not required to reduce the number of immigrant visas available. The Immigration and Nationality Act provisions apply unless specified otherwise in this section. The Immigration and Nationality Act definitions apply to this section. The Attorney General's powers in immigration enforcement are not affected. Eligibility for permanent residence status under this section does not prevent seeking it under other laws. The Visa Fairness Commission is established within the Immigration and Naturalization Service. Its duties include overseeing visa-related matters. The Visa Fairness Commission, in consultation with the Director of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, collects data on economic and racial profiling at American embassies and US points of entry. The Secretary of State is required to waive visa fees for those in forma pauperis status. The Visa Fairness Commission, appointed by the Director of the INS, consists of 15 members representing diverse groups in the US. Appointments can bypass certain regulations, with a limit of 8 members from the same political party. Each member serves a two-year term without pay, except for federal employees who cannot receive compensation. The Commission members, who are full-time US officers or employees, cannot receive extra pay or benefits. Each member receives travel expenses as per US Code. Eight members form a quorum, and a lesser number can hold hearings. The Chairman and Vice Chairman are designated by the INS Director. Meetings are called by the Chairman or a majority of members. SEC. 204. DIRECTOR AND STAFF OF COMMISSION; EXPERTS AND CONSULTANTS. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the Commission, who will be paid at a rate not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. The Director may appoint additional staff as needed, subject to Commission rules. The Director and staff shall be appointed under title 5, United States Code, and paid according to relevant provisions. The Director may procure temporary services under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code, at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission on a reimbursable basis. SEC. 205. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, administer oaths, and obtain necessary information from government agencies to carry out its duties. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission, and the Commission can accept gifts, bequests, and devises. The Commission has the authority to accept gifts, bequests, and devises of services or property to aid its work. It can also use the United States mails and request administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services. Additionally, the Commission has subpoena power. The Commission has subpoena power under the Act, allowing it to issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence related to investigations. Failure to comply with a subpoena may result in a court order to appear before the Commission. The Commission has the power to issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence. Failure to comply may result in a court order for civil contempt. Subpoenas must be served as per the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. Immunity is not granted for refusing to testify or produce evidence. The Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas, and individuals can claim the privilege against self-incrimination. The Commission can also contract with government and private agencies without following certain statutes. The Commission is required to submit an annual report detailing its activities to the Director of the INS and Congress by December 31 each year. Appropriations are authorized as needed for the study. Title III addresses eligibility for adjustment of status under section 245(I), removing certain limitations. Section 245(i) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow certain aliens physically present in the US to apply for adjustment of status to that of a lawful permanent resident.
